GOD.content: trembling in mysterium tremendum? gift of infinite love, dissymmetry btwn gaze of God, and me not seeing what looks at me (gift and endurance of death in irreplaceable) > disproportion btwn infinite gift & my finitude > responsibility: salvation, sin, culpability, sacrifice
GOD.linkedContent: trembling in mysterium tremendum? gift of infinite love, dissymmetry btwn gaze of God, and me not seeing what looks at me (gift and endurance of death in irreplaceable) > disproportion btwn infinite gift & my finitude > responsibility: salvation, sin, culpability, sacrifice

GOD.content: commerce is reciprocal and finite exchange of wages, merchandise, reward; Christ’s economy of sacrifice as dissymmetry, but still payment, wages, merces
GOD.linkedContent: commerce is reciprocal and finite exchange of wages, merchandise, reward; Christ’s economy of sacrifice as dissymmetry, but still payment, wages, merces

GT.content: as long as money counts, produces effects, as long as it assures finite possibilities of decision & judgment, it is simply not different from money it counterfeits > a more powerful but not infinitely powerful [?] inscription of effects of reference on truth, convention, dispositifs
GT.linkedContent: as long as money counts, produces effects, as long as it assures finite possibilities of decision & judgment, it is simply not different from money it counterfeits > a more powerful but not infinitely powerful [?] inscription of effects of reference on truth, convention, dispositifs

GT.content: opposition of conventional to natural is discredited, or, more rigorously, it is limited in its indispensable credit, in the speculation it will always have to authorize
GT.linkedContent: opposition of conventional to natural is discredited, or, more rigorously, it is limited in its indispensable credit, in the speculation it will always have to authorize

R.content: by killing father Cronos (infinite order of time), Zeus wills out over time, touches the finitude of time, sovereignty as the instant of a decision, end to time and language
R.linkedContent: by killing father Cronos (infinite order of time), Zeus wills out over time, touches the finitude of time, sovereignty as the instant of a decision, end to time and language

FK.content: autoimmunity of Christianity w/ capitalism unassignable end, but finite, exhausting itself
FK.linkedContent: autoimmunity of Christianity w/ capitalism unassignable end, but finite, exhausting itself

H.content: host must elect, choose, filter, must have power, no hospitality w/out finitude: Gewalt, force of law
H.linkedContent: host must elect, choose, filter, must have power, no hospitality w/out finitude: Gewalt, force of law

MC.content: [artist as pervert?] art (particularly literature) can isolate performatively its own context for its own event > the “oeuvre”
MC.linkedContent: [artist as pervert?] art (particularly literature) can isolate performatively its own context for its own event > the “oeuvre”

MC.content: this large, stereotomic margin of play is perhaps largest of all (during certain history) but not infinite [?] [see also Christianity/Capitalism not infinite]
MC.linkedContent: this large, stereotomic margin of play is perhaps largest of all (during certain history) but not infinite [?] [see also Christianity/Capitalism not infinite]

FL.content: what else can one love but ruins? one loves a monument in the ghost or silhouette of its ruins? its finitude
FL.linkedContent: what else can one love but ruins? one loves a monument in the ghost or silhouette of its ruins? its finitude

AF.content: no archive drive w/out radical finitude, possibility of forgetfulness, death drive’s threat is infinite, radical evil & political-ethical questions
AF.linkedContent: no archive drive w/out radical finitude, possibility of forgetfulness, death drive’s threat is infinite, radical evil & political-ethical questions

AF.content: archive made possible by destruction drive as originary finitude and expropriation, also no archive fever or desire w/out in-finite movement of radical destruction
AF.linkedContent: archive made possible by destruction drive as originary finitude and expropriation, also no archive fever or desire w/out in-finite movement of radical destruction

OOG.content: sedimentary retention [as habitus, occurs because living consciousness is finite] is general form of protention conceived as unique, universal form of Living Present
OOG.linkedContent: sedimentary retention [as habitus, occurs because living consciousness is finite] is general form of protention conceived as unique, universal form of Living Present

OOG.content: spirit’s radical freedom: theoretical attitude (which the philosopher inaugurates), opens horizon of knowledge as a pre-having beyond finitude
OOG.linkedContent: spirit’s radical freedom: theoretical attitude (which the philosopher inaugurates), opens horizon of knowledge as a pre-having beyond finitude

SPOM.content: we are inheritors of plus d’une parole and an injunction (singular) that is disjointed
SPOM.linkedContent: we are inheritors of plus d’une parole and an injunction (singular) that is disjointed

SPOM.content: injunction of inheritance: “choose and decide from what you inherit” > this choice, like memory, the condition of finitude
SPOM.linkedContent: injunction of inheritance: “choose and decide from what you inherit” > this choice, like memory, the condition of finitude

SPOM.content: jurer ou conjurer: the chance of thinking and its limit? the gift of its finitude? [nous gageons ici que la pensée ne vient jamais à bout de la pulsion conjuratoire]
SPOM.linkedContent: jurer ou conjurer: the chance of thinking and its limit? the gift of its finitude? [nous gageons ici que la pensée ne vient jamais à bout de la pulsion conjuratoire]

HASD.content: trace as possibility of finitude, finite & infinite cause of trace appears secondary, an effect of trace or differance (which is finite insofar as it is infinite)
HASD.linkedContent: trace as possibility of finitude, finite & infinite cause of trace appears secondary, an effect of trace or differance (which is finite insofar as it is infinite)

MPM.content: this finitude (finitude of friendship) does not take the form of a limit, but takes the form of the trace of the other in us, the other’s irreducible presence
MPM.linkedContent: this finitude (finitude of friendship) does not take the form of a limit, but takes the form of the trace of the other in us, the other’s irreducible presence

MPM.content: finitude of memory, formed by trace of other in us > approach or remembrance of future  (memory of mourning, mourning of memory)
MPM.linkedContent: finitude of memory, formed by trace of other in us > approach or remembrance of future (memory of mourning, mourning of memory)

MPM.content: possibility of death of the other in-forms any relation to other & finitude of memory
MPM.linkedContent: possibility of death of the other in-forms any relation to other & finitude of memory

MPM.content: finitude of memory ≠ finite limitation or external limit
MPM.linkedContent: finitude of memory ≠ finite limitation or external limit

MPM.content: undecidable is the condition of deconstruction (on and in [sur, dans?] this condition); in the sense of condition of possibility and, at the same time, condition as situation or destiny
MPM.linkedContent: undecidable is the condition of deconstruction (on and in [sur, dans?] this condition); in the sense of condition of possibility and, at the same time, condition as situation or destiny

MPM.content: this limit, this finitude, makes one write; deconstruction makes a path of writing through the aporia (impossible); deconstruction thinks only on the level of the impossible
MPM.linkedContent: this limit, this finitude, makes one write; deconstruction makes a path of writing through the aporia (impossible); deconstruction thinks only on the level of the impossible

POOF.content: Nietzsche’s overturning, [via dangerous perhaps], brought off in ‘field’ w/out limit, w/out assured, reassuring, ground—all the more finite for this very fact: a world that no longer holds together, one that resembles chaotic madness, disorder, randomness
POOF.linkedContent: Nietzsche’s overturning, [via dangerous perhaps], brought off in ‘field’ w/out limit, w/out assured, reassuring, ground—all the more finite for this very fact: a world that no longer holds together, one that resembles chaotic madness, disorder, randomness

POOF.content: Nietzsche’s gift must also belong to a finite world > how to think dissymmetry of gift w/out exchange, infinite disproportion, from vantage point of terrestrial finitude? under its horizon w/out horizon [see p. 263] > infinitization itself is suspected of being an economic ruse, perverse seduction, stratagem, of loving one’s neighbor
POOF.linkedContent: Nietzsche’s gift must also belong to a finite world > how to think dissymmetry of gift w/out exchange, infinite disproportion, from vantage point of terrestrial finitude? under its horizon w/out horizon [see p. 263] > infinitization itself is suspected of being an economic ruse, perverse seduction, stratagem, of loving one’s neighbor

POOF.content: Nietzsche’s friend of most distant belongs to finite earth (not world of Christian hinterworld) > friend’s finitude infinitizes the gift he gives [infinite differance is finite] : a friend who doesn’t give you the world (a finite one), gives you nothing [this is neither Greek nor Christian]
POOF.linkedContent: Nietzsche’s friend of most distant belongs to finite earth (not world of Christian hinterworld) > friend’s finitude infinitizes the gift he gives [infinite differance is finite] : a friend who doesn’t give you the world (a finite one), gives you nothing [this is neither Greek nor Christian]

A.content: as soon as truth is confined (determined to be finished) a border crossing does not seem impossible; there’s something else than truth, something better, truth is finite, c’est fini
A.linkedContent: as soon as truth is confined (determined to be finished) a border crossing does not seem impossible; there’s something else than truth, something better, truth is finite, c’est fini

A.content: for Heidegger, belief in immortality is secondary to being-toward-death, an affirmation of an originary finitude Hegel thought he reversed in Kant [the originary, underivable character of death, of finitude, forces us to decide on undecidable]
A.linkedContent: for Heidegger, belief in immortality is secondary to being-toward-death, an affirmation of an originary finitude Hegel thought he reversed in Kant [the originary, underivable character of death, of finitude, forces us to decide on undecidable]

A.content: Heidegger’s on Kant’s side, on this side of finitude > didn’t Hegel want to show unilaterality of border, and that one is already on the other side of the here?
A.linkedContent: Heidegger’s on Kant’s side, on this side of finitude > didn’t Hegel want to show unilaterality of border, and that one is already on the other side of the here?

EM.content: phenomenology as relève of anthropology, no longer but still a science of man
EM.linkedContent: phenomenology as relève of anthropology, no longer but still a science of man

EM.content: in all structures described in Phenom… l’homme y reste en son relief, equivocal relation to relief (relevance) marque sans doute la fin de l’homme, man past, but also achievement of man > c’est la fin de l’homme fini, end of finitude of man, unity of infinite and finite
EM.linkedContent: in all structures described in Phenom… l’homme y reste en son relief, equivocal relation to relief (relevance) marque sans doute la fin de l’homme, man past, but also achievement of man > c’est la fin de l’homme fini, end of finitude of man, unity of infinite and finite

EM.content: the relevance accomplished in Hegelian metaphysics persists wherever metaphysics, our language, maintains its authority, even in pre-Hegelian systems (i.e. in Kant, figure of finitude organizes capacity to know from emergence of anthropological limit)
EM.linkedContent: the relevance accomplished in Hegelian metaphysics persists wherever metaphysics, our language, maintains its authority, even in pre-Hegelian systems (i.e. in Kant, figure of finitude organizes capacity to know from emergence of anthropological limit)

EM.content: “man” only has meaning in eschato-teleological situation, inscribed in metaphysics btwn 2 ends: 1) transcendental end 2) mortality, finitude
EM.linkedContent: “man” only has meaning in eschato-teleological situation, inscribed in metaphysics btwn 2 ends: 1) transcendental end 2) mortality, finitude

EM.content: finitude as origin of, that which unfolds, ideality
EM.linkedContent: finitude as origin of, that which unfolds, ideality

EM.content: prescription of the end of man, prescribed since always, has done nothing but “modulate equivocality of the end, in the play of telos and death”
EM.linkedContent: prescription of the end of man, prescribed since always, has done nothing but “modulate equivocality of the end, in the play of telos and death”

EM.content: dans la lecture de ce jeu: le fin de l’homme est la pensée de l’être, l’homme est la fin de la pensée de l’être, la fin de l’homme est la fin de la pensée de l’être > l’homme est depuis toujours sa propre fin, c’est-a-dire la fin de son propre > l’être est depuis toujours sa propre fin, c’est-à-dire la fin de son propre
EM.linkedContent: dans la lecture de ce jeu: le fin de l’homme est la pensée de l’être, l’homme est la fin de la pensée de l’être, la fin de l’homme est la fin de la pensée de l’être > l’homme est depuis toujours sa propre fin, c’est-a-dire la fin de son propre > l’être est depuis toujours sa propre fin, c’est-à-dire la fin de son propre

VM.content: w/in thought of original finitude, how could writing be secondary?
VM.linkedContent: w/in thought of original finitude, how could writing be secondary?

VM.content: for Levinas, asymmetry, non-light, commandment are violence and injustice only in relation to finite things, Levinas’ infinite God avoids a world of pure/worst violence, of immorality itself, by being infinite, does not rage war of single, naked finite man
VM.linkedContent: for Levinas, asymmetry, non-light, commandment are violence and injustice only in relation to finite things, Levinas’ infinite God avoids a world of pure/worst violence, of immorality itself, by being infinite, does not rage war of single, naked finite man

VM.content: for Levinas, totality is always finite totality
VM.linkedContent: for Levinas, totality is always finite totality

VM.content: war played out btwn face and finite world w/out a face, isn’t this the difference in which absence-presence of God plays? wouldn’t this play precede God, permit us to think his essence?
VM.linkedContent: war played out btwn face and finite world w/out a face, isn’t this the difference in which absence-presence of God plays? wouldn’t this play precede God, permit us to think his essence?

VM.content: dissociation of thought and language, subordination of latter to former, is proper to philosophy of finitude [Cartesian Cogito of 3rd Meditation]
VM.linkedContent: dissociation of thought and language, subordination of latter to former, is proper to philosophy of finitude [Cartesian Cogito of 3rd Meditation]

VM.content: space as wound and finitude of birth
VM.linkedContent: space as wound and finitude of birth

VM.content: [does Levinas try to preserve positive infinity alongside spatiality of face? should he name finite what he names infinitely other if it must pass through space, negation?]
VM.linkedContent: [does Levinas try to preserve positive infinity alongside spatiality of face? should he name finite what he names infinitely other if it must pass through space, negation?]

VM.content: all philosophies that do not distinguish btwn thought and language are philosophies of original finitude, can they abandon this word, or are they prisoners to a classical framework?
VM.linkedContent: all philosophies that do not distinguish btwn thought and language are philosophies of original finitude, can they abandon this word, or are they prisoners to a classical framework?

VM.content: infinite alterity as irreducibly common horizon of Death and the Other, horizon of finitude, finitude of horizon
VM.linkedContent: infinite alterity as irreducibly common horizon of Death and the Other, horizon of finitude, finitude of horizon

VM.content: avoid the worst by vigilance that takes finitude (history) seriously: that fights light w/ light: philosopher must speak and write w/in this war of light, in which he knows he’s already engaged; the worst is night, which precedes or represses discourse
VM.linkedContent: avoid the worst by vigilance that takes finitude (history) seriously: that fights light w/ light: philosopher must speak and write w/in this war of light, in which he knows he’s already engaged; the worst is night, which precedes or represses discourse

VM.content: an economy of violence (economy irreducible to Levinas’ definition) that tolerates neither finite totality, nor positive infinity
VM.linkedContent: an economy of violence (economy irreducible to Levinas’ definition) that tolerates neither finite totality, nor positive infinity

VM.content: only way to escape Hegel, for an instant, consider “false infinity,” original finitude, irreducible
VM.linkedContent: only way to escape Hegel, for an instant, consider “false infinity,” original finitude, irreducible

VM.content: for Levinas, if Husserlian Cogito opened to infinite, it would be an object-infinity w/out alterity, a “false infinity” [Levinas never uses this Hegelian term, but idea of indefinite, negative form of infinity haunts his gestures]; Levinas makes true alterity nonnegativity, and the same (complicit w/ negativity) the false-infinity > would have seemed absolutely mad to Hegel
VM.linkedContent: for Levinas, if Husserlian Cogito opened to infinite, it would be an object-infinity w/out alterity, a “false infinity” [Levinas never uses this Hegelian term, but idea of indefinite, negative form of infinity haunts his gestures]; Levinas makes true alterity nonnegativity, and the same (complicit w/ negativity) the false-infinity > would have seemed absolutely mad to Hegel

VM.content: that other as such only appears in relation to same is violence as origin of meaning and of discourse in reign of finitude
VM.linkedContent: that other as such only appears in relation to same is violence as origin of meaning and of discourse in reign of finitude

VM.content: infinitely other & infinitely same, if they have meaning for a finite being, is the same
VM.linkedContent: infinitely other & infinitely same, if they have meaning for a finite being, is the same

VM.content: btwn original tragedy and messianic triumph there is philosophy, in which violence returned against violence, in which original finitude appears, in which other is respected w/in, by, the same ——question of philosophy: why finitude? why must I think transcendental through ego, ipseity?
VM.linkedContent: btwn original tragedy and messianic triumph there is philosophy, in which violence returned against violence, in which original finitude appears, in which other is respected w/in, by, the same ——question of philosophy: why finitude? why must I think transcendental through ego, ipseity?

VM.content: for Husserl (transcendental phenomenology), “subjective a priori” only way to check totalitarianism of the neutral, impersonal “absolute Logic”: eschatology w/out dialogue [re: why finitude?] [revelation through faulty teletype]
VM.linkedContent: for Husserl (transcendental phenomenology), “subjective a priori” only way to check totalitarianism of the neutral, impersonal “absolute Logic”: eschatology w/out dialogue [re: why finitude?] [revelation through faulty teletype]

VM.content: origin of question why finitude? why why? transcendental archi-factuality as violence? > naked, silent opening of question escapes phenomenology, permits appearance of history as such: it is the call (to) (of) an eschatology that dissimulates its own opening
VM.linkedContent: origin of question why finitude? why why? transcendental archi-factuality as violence? > naked, silent opening of question escapes phenomenology, permits appearance of history as such: it is the call (to) (of) an eschatology that dissimulates its own opening

VM.content: opening of question, inversion of transcendental dissymmetry, put to philosophy as logos, finitude, history, violence: interpellation of Greek by non-Greek, strange community of silent question > la phénoménologie et l’eschatologie peuvent interminablement entamer le dialogue, s’entamer en lui, s’appeler l’une l’autre au silence ——question “why finitude?” can be stated only by being forgotten in language of Greeks
VM.linkedContent: opening of question, inversion of transcendental dissymmetry, put to philosophy as logos, finitude, history, violence: interpellation of Greek by non-Greek, strange community of silent question > la phénoménologie et l’eschatologie peuvent interminablement entamer le dialogue, s’entamer en lui, s’appeler l’une l’autre au silence ——question “why finitude?” can be stated only by being forgotten in language of Greeks

VM.content: if other can only be respected/dissimulated by the same, then time is violence, living present originally marked by death > “presence as violence is the meaning of finitude, meaning of meaning as history”
VM.linkedContent: if other can only be respected/dissimulated by the same, then time is violence, living present originally marked by death > “presence as violence is the meaning of finitude, meaning of meaning as history”

VM.content: Malebranche says Being is infinitely slight because infinite; Heidegger says Being is nothing (determined), produced in difference (as difference), that it is produced “in simultaneity with” Nothingness, it is “finite in its essence” [VP p. 87 the infinite differance is finite]
VM.linkedContent: Malebranche says Being is infinitely slight because infinite; Heidegger says Being is nothing (determined), produced in difference (as difference), that it is produced “in simultaneity with” Nothingness, it is “finite in its essence” [VP p. 87 the infinite differance is finite]

VM.content: Heidegger stops using Endlichkeit, it was never Christian-theological but idea of finite Being is ontotheological
VM.linkedContent: Heidegger stops using Endlichkeit, it was never Christian-theological but idea of finite Being is ontotheological

VM.content: thought that seeks to go to its very end in its language, the end envisaged under name of finitude, should abandon words & themes of finite/infinite & everything they govern > this is the impossible of beyond metaphysics which confirms necessity for this incommensurable overflow to take support from metaphysics
VM.linkedContent: thought that seeks to go to its very end in its language, the end envisaged under name of finitude, should abandon words & themes of finite/infinite & everything they govern > this is the impossible of beyond metaphysics which confirms necessity for this incommensurable overflow to take support from metaphysics

VM.content: Heidegger realized this in making difference [btwn Being & existent] fundamental
VM.linkedContent: Heidegger realized this in making difference [btwn Being & existent] fundamental

OH.content: there is a crisis whenever the capital of infinity and universality finds itself in danger, when the eidos, limits, ends, confines, the finitude of Europe, emerges
OH.linkedContent: there is a crisis whenever the capital of infinity and universality finds itself in danger, when the eidos, limits, ends, confines, the finitude of Europe, emerges

VP.content: ideality of the form of presence can be repeated to infinity as return of the same, but retained in a finite movement
VP.linkedContent: ideality of the form of presence can be repeated to infinity as return of the same, but retained in a finite movement

FSW.content: logo-phonocentrism is necessary and necessarily finite [Derrida’s faith?] > history of the possibility of symbolism
FSW.linkedContent: logo-phonocentrism is necessary and necessarily finite [Derrida’s faith?] > history of the possibility of symbolism

FSW.content: instead of machine being a pure absence of spontaneity, its resemblance to psychical apparatus bears witness to finitude of mnemic spontaneity thus supplemented
FSW.linkedContent: instead of machine being a pure absence of spontaneity, its resemblance to psychical apparatus bears witness to finitude of mnemic spontaneity thus supplemented

FSW.content: machine and thus representation is death and finitude w/in psyche, idea of finitude derived from movement of supplementarity
FSW.linkedContent: machine and thus representation is death and finitude w/in psyche, idea of finitude derived from movement of supplementarity

TC.content: following Artaud, Derrida describes a dialectic outside conventional Hegelianism > the indefinite movement of finitude, original repetition, origin of tragedy as absence of simple origin: dialectics as tragedy, only possible affirmation to be made against idea of pure origin
TC.linkedContent: following Artaud, Derrida describes a dialectic outside conventional Hegelianism > the indefinite movement of finitude, original repetition, origin of tragedy as absence of simple origin: dialectics as tragedy, only possible affirmation to be made against idea of pure origin

SH.linkedContent: date makes question “what is?” finite

FWT.content: contradictory tasks set to us by inheritance is a testimony to our finitude: finitude obliges us to inherit what is older, more powerful, more durable; same finitude obliges one to choose, select, sacrifice, exclude, let go, leave behind
FWT.linkedContent: contradictory tasks set to us by inheritance is a testimony to our finitude: finitude obliges us to inherit what is older, more powerful, more durable; same finitude obliges one to choose, select, sacrifice, exclude, let go, leave behind

FWT.content: literature a recent invention, threatened by death, repeats its birth beginning from its end, from a finitude that is its resource & essential specter
FWT.linkedContent: literature a recent invention, threatened by death, repeats its birth beginning from its end, from a finitude that is its resource & essential specter

OS.content: in analytic of Dasein, relation of fall to proper, authenticity, enigmatic proximity (identity w/ itself of the questioning), concept of finitude
OS.linkedContent: in analytic of Dasein, relation of fall to proper, authenticity, enigmatic proximity (identity w/ itself of the questioning), concept of finitude

ROP.content: instead of “failure” of archaeological principle [of analysis], this principle is destined to limit of its arrest, finitude of its suspense > there’s chance in falling-due, given of fall
ROP.linkedContent: instead of “failure” of archaeological principle [of analysis], this principle is destined to limit of its arrest, finitude of its suspense > there’s chance in falling-due, given of fall

ROP.content: acc. Foucault, Freud introduces modernity to “originary finitude” by accounting for death (Derrida wonders if this wouldn’t put Freud on the side of madness w/ Nietzsche)
ROP.linkedContent: acc. Foucault, Freud introduces modernity to “originary finitude” by accounting for death (Derrida wonders if this wouldn’t put Freud on the side of madness w/ Nietzsche)

ROP.content: finitude is derived for Kant, while it is originary for Heidegger
ROP.linkedContent: finitude is derived for Kant, while it is originary for Heidegger

ATIA.content: that God wants to see Ish name the animals marks God as infinite, all-powerful, and finite > God does not know what will happen to him w/ language (doesn’t know what he wants)
ATIA.linkedContent: that God wants to see Ish name the animals marks God as infinite, all-powerful, and finite > God does not know what will happen to him w/ language (doesn’t know what he wants)

ATIA.content: finitude of “I think” (anthropologism) is denied the animal by Heidegger & Kant
ATIA.linkedContent: finitude of “I think” (anthropologism) is denied the animal by Heidegger & Kant

PS.content: (with remarkable/ambiguous exception of Hegel) God is Death: infinite life, life w/out difference > w/in life God-Death names finitude, difference w/in life > mais l'autre nom de la même chose ne veut pas dire la même chose que le premier nom, il n'en est pas synonyme et c'est toute l’histoire
PS.linkedContent: (with remarkable/ambiguous exception of Hegel) God is Death: infinite life, life w/out difference > w/in life God-Death names finitude, difference w/in life > mais l'autre nom de la même chose ne veut pas dire la même chose que le premier nom, il n'en est pas synonyme et c'est toute l’histoire

FS.content: for Leibniz, man is finite in act, infinite in thought; in God, thought/action coexist
FS.linkedContent: for Leibniz, man is finite in act, infinite in thought; in God, thought/action coexist

FS.content: attempt-to-write, moment of overflow (can’t be understand via voluntarism): when play of meaning overflows signification, which is always enveloped by limits of nature, life, soul
FS.linkedContent: attempt-to-write, moment of overflow (can’t be understand via voluntarism): when play of meaning overflows signification, which is always enveloped by limits of nature, life, soul

FS.content: the project of infinite tradition must be acknowledged as such: that it can always fail is the mark of its pure finitude/pure historicity
FS.linkedContent: the project of infinite tradition must be acknowledged as such: that it can always fail is the mark of its pure finitude/pure historicity

WAP.content: institution can forget its own elect (finite memory), its finitude also affects remembrance of what it wants to exclude: the surface of its archive thus inscribed w/ what it refuses, excludes (ex: Walter Benjamin not receiving a degree)
WAP.linkedContent: institution can forget its own elect (finite memory), its finitude also affects remembrance of what it wants to exclude: the surface of its archive thus inscribed w/ what it refuses, excludes (ex: Walter Benjamin not receiving a degree)

DPi.content: abolitionists as eternalists fearing death, full of guilt [suspicion of a Nietzschean/Baudelairean cast], the evil of finitude, fallible finitude > for Baudelaire, these fearful men confess w/symptom of their abolitionism, an infinite protest against mortality
DPi.linkedContent: abolitionists as eternalists fearing death, full of guilt [suspicion of a Nietzschean/Baudelairean cast], the evil of finitude, fallible finitude > for Baudelaire, these fearful men confess w/symptom of their abolitionism, an infinite protest against mortality

DPi.content: DP ends finitude of “my life” > w/ calendar
it is because my life is finite, “ended,” that I keep this relation to incalculability and undecidability as to the instant of my death
DPi.linkedContent: it is because my life is finite, “ended,” that I keep this relation to incalculability and undecidability as to the instant of my death

DPi.content: DP masters future through machines, or purports to, deprives me of my own finitude, exonerates me of my experience of finitude > thus the seductive fascination it exerts on side of condemning power and side of condemned > fascinated by power of calculation, end of finitude, end of of anxiety, protects against irruption of other > all this decidability remains phantasms > origin of phantasms in general—and perhaps of religion
DPi.linkedContent: DP masters future through machines, or purports to, deprives me of my own finitude, exonerates me of my experience of finitude > thus the seductive fascination it exerts on side of condemning power and side of condemned > fascinated by power of calculation, end of finitude, end of of anxiety, protects against irruption of other > all this decidability remains phantasms > origin of phantasms in general—and perhaps of religion

DPi.content: phantasm of end of finitude, the other side of an infinitization, is constitutive of finitude outside any real scene of verdict/DP [?] > DP thus an acting out or an effect of truth re: our own dreams of infinite survival assured by a calculated, decisive, interruption: in these dreams we play the role of judge, jury, executioner, assistants, the condemned > force of this phantasm so strong will probably guarantee forever the double survival of DP and abolitionist protest
DPi.linkedContent: phantasm of end of finitude, the other side of an infinitization, is constitutive of finitude outside any real scene of verdict/DP [?] > DP thus an acting out or an effect of truth re: our own dreams of infinite survival assured by a calculated, decisive, interruption: in these dreams we play the role of judge, jury, executioner, assistants, the condemned > force of this phantasm so strong will probably guarantee forever the double survival of DP and abolitionist protest

DPi.content: phantasm of infinitization at heart of finitude [dream of a verdict, the putting an end to finitude], theologico-political, an infinitization of survival assured by calculation itself, by cutting decision of DP, phantasm is one w/ God, belief in God
DPi.linkedContent: phantasm of infinitization at heart of finitude [dream of a verdict, the putting an end to finitude], theologico-political, an infinitization of survival assured by calculation itself, by cutting decision of DP, phantasm is one w/ God, belief in God

DST.content: how could a thinker of finitude, Heidegger, never avoid anything (ne jamais rien éviter)?
DST.linkedContent: how could a thinker of finitude, Heidegger, never avoid anything (ne jamais rien éviter)?

PIO.content: aleatory event of tout autre, beyond the incalculable as a still possible calculus [p. 45], et ne peut advenir que pour un être fini [only happens to a finite being]: la chance même de la finitude > what happens thus (échoit ainsi) is how finitude invents and appears to itself
PIO.linkedContent: aleatory event of tout autre, beyond the incalculable as a still possible calculus [p. 45], et ne peut advenir que pour un être fini [only happens to a finite being]: la chance même de la finitude > what happens thus (échoit ainsi) is how finitude invents and appears to itself

PF.content: perjurer can always give alibi: I was elsewhere, I wasn’t thinking (his finitude as alibi)
PF.linkedContent: perjurer can always give alibi: I was elsewhere, I wasn’t thinking (his finitude as alibi)

TR.content: paradoxical antinomy of performative & event, the former neutralizes event in “I can” of mastery: vulnerability/finitude of body & corpus is limit of performative power
TR.linkedContent: paradoxical antinomy of performative & event, the former neutralizes event in “I can” of mastery: vulnerability/finitude of body & corpus is limit of performative power

PJP.content: one cannot expect a finite subject to think/remember, at every instant, all ethical obligations he should answer > inhuman, indecent [Mount Moriah of GOD]
PJP.linkedContent: one cannot expect a finite subject to think/remember, at every instant, all ethical obligations he should answer > inhuman, indecent [Mount Moriah of GOD]

PJP.content: essential finitude of discontinuous anamnesis inscribes ellipses/eclipses in identity of subject
PJP.linkedContent: essential finitude of discontinuous anamnesis inscribes ellipses/eclipses in identity of subject

PJP.content: undecided btwn provocative irony, disarming sincerity: one responds both responsibly & irresponsibly
PJP.linkedContent: undecided btwn provocative irony, disarming sincerity: one responds both responsibly & irresponsibly

PJP.content: amnesia, irreducible distraction, disappearance at heart of finite thought: the resource, power of anacoluthon [see p. 194]
PJP.linkedContent: amnesia, irreducible distraction, disappearance at heart of finite thought: the resource, power of anacoluthon [see p. 194]

PJP.content: narrative of a disappearance: signature gets erased moment it enters literature [like question in EJQB]
PJP.linkedContent: narrative of a disappearance: signature gets erased moment it enters literature [like question in EJQB]

PSSS.content: psychoanalysis is ineradicable, its revolution is irreversible—yet, like civilization, it’s mortal
PSSS.linkedContent: psychoanalysis is ineradicable, its revolution is irreversible—yet, like civilization, it’s mortal

HST.content: impossibility of forgiveness must be thought onto la racine la plus radicale of its paradox—it does not resist the impossibility of what wants to be conceived in it > concept of concept undergoes l’épreuve of its essential precariousness, its finitude, its deconstructability
HST.linkedContent: impossibility of forgiveness must be thought onto la racine la plus radicale of its paradox—it does not resist the impossibility of what wants to be conceived in it > concept of concept undergoes l’épreuve of its essential precariousness, its finitude, its deconstructability

PPT.content: trait acts as a passe-partout: multiplies dealings and transactions (contraband, graft and parasitizing among them); still, passe-partout must formally answer to finite system of constraints
PPT.linkedContent: trait acts as a passe-partout: multiplies dealings and transactions (contraband, graft and parasitizing among them); still, passe-partout must formally answer to finite system of constraints

LI.content: [Derrida admits to lack of rigor] “engendering” an infinity of new contexts [from SEC] should be replaced by “engendering & inscribing itself,” or being inscribed in > for a context never creates itself ex nihilo, can’t create context on its own, can’t dominate a context either > this limit, finitude, is the condition by which contextual transformations remain possible
LI.linkedContent: [Derrida admits to lack of rigor] “engendering” an infinity of new contexts [from SEC] should be replaced by “engendering & inscribing itself,” or being inscribed in > for a context never creates itself ex nihilo, can’t create context on its own, can’t dominate a context either > this limit, finitude, is the condition by which contextual transformations remain possible

TN.content: the haptical, for every finite existence, recalls what is coming [Socrates], marks the limit at which or from which the presentation announces itself
TN.linkedContent: the haptical, for every finite existence, recalls what is coming [Socrates], marks the limit at which or from which the presentation announces itself

TN.content: touch is finitude, period, stop at this point > l’efforcement (forceful exertion) always signs a finitude
TN.linkedContent: touch is finitude, period, stop at this point > l’efforcement (forceful exertion) always signs a finitude

TN.content: Chrétian admits to a veil in finite touch, a “phenomenological occultation” of the creature
TN.linkedContent: Chrétian admits to a veil in finite touch, a “phenomenological occultation” of the creature

TN.content: spacing & “distance” are thought by Chrétian [by Christian theology of flesh], reduced to phenomenology of finitude, que le toucher spirituel (infini, immédiat, etc.) aura commencé par élever et relever [differance serving to close closure]
TN.linkedContent: spacing & “distance” are thought by Chrétian [by Christian theology of flesh], reduced to phenomenology of finitude, que le toucher spirituel (infini, immédiat, etc.) aura commencé par élever et relever [differance serving to close closure]

TN.content: incarnation will never be phenomenon of an irreducible finitude
TN.linkedContent: incarnation will never be phenomenon of an irreducible finitude

TN.content: finite thinking: a limit that thinking touches w/out appropriating it for itself
TN.linkedContent: finite thinking: a limit that thinking touches w/out appropriating it for itself

TN.content: diastole w/out systole, interruption risks death at every moment, other heart se touche toi only to be exteposed to death: toi es (t) aussi ma mort [at heart of a finite thinking]
TN.linkedContent: diastole w/out systole, interruption risks death at every moment, other heart se touche toi only to be exteposed to death: toi es (t) aussi ma mort [at heart of a finite thinking]

NOY.content: Nietzsche opposes Ja of innocent affirmation with Ja, Ja of the Christian ass
NOY.linkedContent: Nietzsche opposes Ja of innocent affirmation with Ja, Ja of the Christian ass

NOY.content: Christian yes, a yes of finitude (repetition and memory); Derrida proposes a more ancient root to annul the alternative [limitless singular yes, finite ass yes]
NOY.linkedContent: Christian yes, a yes of finitude (repetition and memory); Derrida proposes a more ancient root to annul the alternative [limitless singular yes, finite ass yes]

AD.content: Levinas: à-Dieu is infinitely older than finite, diachrony of time “being destined” before any act of consciousness, destined as devotion itself, desire refers to à-Dieu, which is more profound, older than cogito
AD.linkedContent: Levinas: à-Dieu is infinitely older than finite, diachrony of time “being destined” before any act of consciousness, destined as devotion itself, desire refers to à-Dieu, which is more profound, older than cogito

BSi.content: for Derrida, hypothesis that bêtise always threatens imperturbable ithyphallus is the essential ithyphallic bêtise > ithyphallus’ hyperbolical desire is nil/empty of thought, this void pushes, pulses, compulses, makes one think of a drive that is absolutely bête, never gives up anything, absolute stranger to all thought
BSi.linkedContent: for Derrida, hypothesis that bêtise always threatens imperturbable ithyphallus is the essential ithyphallic bêtise > ithyphallus’ hyperbolical desire is nil/empty of thought, this void pushes, pulses, compulses, makes one think of a drive that is absolutely bête, never gives up anything, absolute stranger to all thought

BSi.content: priapism is infinite ithyphallism, foreign to finitude of erection (finitude makes erection possible) > thus, is detumescence castration?
BSi.linkedContent: priapism is infinite ithyphallism, foreign to finitude of erection (finitude makes erection possible) > thus, is detumescence castration?

OG.content: crisis also a symptom: inflation of language, of sign “language,” inflation of sign itself, inflation itself > language’s historico-metaphysical epoch must determine totality of its problematic horizon, exposing its finitude when no longer self-assured, guaranteed (bordé), by infinite signified (which seemed to exceed it)
OG.linkedContent: crisis also a symptom: inflation of language, of sign “language,” inflation of sign itself, inflation itself > language’s historico-metaphysical epoch must determine totality of its problematic horizon, exposing its finitude when no longer self-assured, guaranteed (bordé), by infinite signified (which seemed to exceed it)

OG.content: acc. Hegel, writing (an Umweg) betrays life/breath > finitude/paralysis, sterilizes spirit, principle of difference/death in becoming of being (is to speech, what China is to Europe)
OG.linkedContent: acc. Hegel, writing (an Umweg) betrays life/breath > finitude/paralysis, sterilizes spirit, principle of difference/death in becoming of being (is to speech, what China is to Europe)

OG.content: “God’s death” & “return to finitude” belong to onto-theology they fight against > differance something other than finitude
OG.linkedContent: “God’s death” & “return to finitude” belong to onto-theology they fight against > differance something other than finitude

OG.content: forgetting & repression inadequate ideas to explain finitude and dissimulation
OG.linkedContent: forgetting & repression inadequate ideas to explain finitude and dissimulation

EU.content: [vis-à-vis Kant] metaphysics as the teacher’s mistress (maîtresse du maître), as censor > for a teacher, a finite being, no lifting of censorship, only strategic calculation: censorship against censorship, debate of the best censorship [the idea of philosopher’s legislation found everywhere in man’s reason], censorship of reason: [Derrida asks vis-à-vis Schelling] is this strategy an art?
EU.linkedContent: [vis-à-vis Kant] metaphysics as the teacher’s mistress (maîtresse du maître), as censor > for a teacher, a finite being, no lifting of censorship, only strategic calculation: censorship against censorship, debate of the best censorship [the idea of philosopher’s legislation found everywhere in man’s reason], censorship of reason: [Derrida asks vis-à-vis Schelling] is this strategy an art?

EU.content: for Schelling, philosopher develops negative condition: consciousness of inanity of all finite knowledge > ability to translate, re-translate, the real to the ideal can be acquired—can be cultivated in a Bildung and become untransformable habitus, unalterable organ
EU.linkedContent: for Schelling, philosopher develops negative condition: consciousness of inanity of all finite knowledge > ability to translate, re-translate, the real to the ideal can be acquired—can be cultivated in a Bildung and become untransformable habitus, unalterable organ

EU.content: most post-Kantians (incl. Nietzsche [?]) claim to have already reached the inaccessible: to think finitude, you have already thought the infinite (this becomes definition of thinking)
EU.linkedContent: most post-Kantians (incl. Nietzsche [?]) claim to have already reached the inaccessible: to think finitude, you have already thought the infinite (this becomes definition of thinking)

EU.content: post-Kantians accuse Kant of founding “criticism” in denegation, more responsible to found thought in inaccessible
EU.linkedContent: post-Kantians accuse Kant of founding “criticism” in denegation, more responsible to found thought in inaccessible

EU.content: for Schelling, individuals, who are finite, must translate > if mind could simply be infinite, there’d be no need to translate > “originary knowledge” can become “real" in an individual, only in der Gattung (in the genus), i.e. in historical institutions > history: becoming-real of idea
EU.linkedContent: for Schelling, individuals, who are finite, must translate > if mind could simply be infinite, there’d be no need to translate > “originary knowledge” can become “real" in an individual, only in der Gattung (in the genus), i.e. in historical institutions > history: becoming-real of idea
